Award.AwardTitle: Terahertz Spectroscopy of Polymorphism in Complex Molecular Solids
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Timothy M. Korter of Syracuse University and his graduate student and colleagues are investigating analytical spectroscopic methods for investigating crystalline polymorphs of molecular solids. The production of crystalline polymorphs in pharmaceutical formulations is increasingly important, yet the methods for analyzing these differing crystalline forms are still in their infancy. Progress in this area could yield to improved formulations in the pharmaceutical industry. The young scientists working on this project will receive training in modern methods in experimental and computational chemistry.

Prof. Korter and his group will combine computational chemistry approaches as well as state-of-the-art Terahertz (THz) spectroscopy to probe the vibrations of molecules in crystals. The fundamental aim of this work is to develop an improved understanding in the subtle ways that complex molecules interact in the solid phase, with the goal of developing a better understanding of existence and underlying processes that give rise to crystalline polymorphism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the research project is to utilize terahertz (THz) spectroscopy and solid-state density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the polymorphic flexibility of complex crystalline molecules ranging from pharmaceuticals to proteins, and improve our understanding of the existence and the underlying processes of polymorphism. Polymorphism is the ability of molecules to achieve multiple stable solid-state forms (polymorphs) that do not change the identity of the molecules, but can dramatically alter physical properties such as melting points or aqueous solubilities through alteration of the intermolecular forces. Low-frequency (<100 cm-1) THz vibrational spectroscopy is an extraordinarily sensitive tool for probing the interactions between molecules in the solid state. It offers insights into intermolecular forces by directly investigating the delocalized global molecular vibrations (e.g. torsions) that are strongly influenced by the chemical environment or accessing the unique vibrations that originate from the bulk solid itself (e.g. lattice vibrations). Investigating these motions through the combination of careful experimentation and rigorous quantum mechanical theory provides detailed knowledge of the intermolecular potential energy surfaces in these materials. Mapping these energy surfaces is a critical step in achieving a fundamental understanding of chemical phenomena such as polymorphic phase transitions and the bioavailability (solubility) of drugs.

There are three main intellectual merit impacts of the research accomplished during this project. First, it has been definitely demonstrated that solid-state DFT is the gold standard when it comes to simulating and assigning the THz spectra of complicated molecular crystals. Combining THz spectroscopy with solid-state density functional theory has provide new and useful insights into phase transformations that exceeds what is possible by either technique alone. Second, it was discovered in this project that THz spectroscopy can be coupled with solid-state density functional theory to measure the mechanical elasticity of very complicated biopolymers samples, which is an exceedingly difficult thing to do any other way. Third, the explicit and accurate theoretical treatment of water or other small solvent molecules that are incorporated into crystalline solids is needed in the interpretation of THz spectra and the understanding of polymorph stabilities. Specifically, it was found that intermolecular force strengths between molecules could be quantified and verified with a synergistic combination of theory and experiment.

There are several broader impacts of this work important to other disciplines, even those outside of chemistry, but the three main areas are as follows. First, the work on energetic factors of co-crystallization in organic molecular crystals and the assignment of THz spectral features (e.g. glutamic acid polymorphs and sorbitol/mannitol hydrates) has made THz spectroscopy a more attractive analytical tool to researchers in pharmaceutical manufacturing and materials science. Second, the research published on THz spectroscopy of pigments (iron sulfate hydrates and quinacridone variants) provides a new tool that will be embraced by both art historians and conservationists for the non-destructive testing of delicate artifacts. Finally, the discovery that THz spectroscopy can measure polymer elasticities will transform the way in which biochemists and polymer scientists measure elasticity and use it for the tuning pf physical properties. This was exemplified during this project in the publication of poly-L-proline polymorph THz data, as illustrated in the accompanying Figure.
